intro: Heracleum sphondylium var. atlanticum, commonly known as the Atlantic cow parsnip, is a perennial herb native to coastal regions of the northeastern United States. It features a tall, hollow stem that can reach up to 2 meters in height, often with a purple tinge. The plant has large, compound leaves that are deeply lobed and can grow up to 30 centimeters in length. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in umbrella-like clusters called umbels, typical of the carrot family. The plant is characterized by its strong, often unpleasant odor and is considered a common weed in disturbed coastal habitats.
